channel.title: math.KT updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.KT updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Horrocks theorem for odd orthogonal groups
item.description: arXiv:2506.10360v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We prove Horrocks' theorem for the odd elementary orthogonal group, which gives a decomposition of an orthogonal matrix with entries from a polynomial ring $R[X]$, over a commutative ring $R$ in which 2 is invertible, as a product of an orthogonal matrix with entries in $R$ and an elementary orthogonal matrix with entries from $R[X]$.
item.dc:creator: Ambily A A, Sugilesh H

item.title: Large-scale quantization of trace I: Finite propagation operators
item.description: arXiv:2506.10957v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Inspired by parallel developments in coarse geometry in mathematics and exact macroscopic quantization in physics, we present a family of general trace formulae which are universally quantized and depend only on large-scale geometric features of the input data. They generalize, to arbitrary dimensions, formulae found by Roe in his partitioned manifold index theorem, as well as the Kubo and Kitaev formulae for 2D Hall conductance used in physics.
item.dc:creator: Matthias Ludewig, Guo Chuan Thiang

item.title: Uniqueness of six-functor formalisms
item.description: arXiv:2412.15780v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We present an alternative formulation of Scholze's notions of cohomologically proper and cohomologically \'etale with respect to an abstract six-functor formalism. These conditions guarantee canonical isomorphisms between the direct and exceptional direct images for certain "proper" morphisms, and between the inverse and exceptional inverse images for certain "\'etale" morphisms. Using this framework, we prove Scholze's conjecture, showing that a six-functor formalism with sufficiently many cohomologically proper and \'etale morphisms is uniquely determined by the tensor product and inverse image functors, and can be obtained by a construction of Liu-Zheng and Mann. Additionally, we show that a generalisation of the conjecture fails, and propose a measure of this failure in terms of K-theory.
item.dc:creator: Adam Dauser, Josefien Kuijper
